awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Undergraduate Research Experience in Biomedical Translational Science and Technology Development
awd_abstract_narration:
The rapid expansion of biomedical science has resulted in a short supply of biomedical scientists and engineers at all career levels, presenting an immediate need to educate and train more young people in the skills and knowledge required for biomedical science and engineering. To meet this demand, Binghamton University (BU-SUNY) will host a 10-week summer REU program to train 10 undergraduate students per year in translational biomedical science and engineering. The program will offer undergraduates intensive multidisciplinary hands-on research and professional development training in integrated biomedical translational science and technology development. The program is anticipated to develop a leadership pipeline helping students advance in either their graduate studies or career and professional training in these fields. The teaming of biomedical scientists with engineers has led to the development of this novel and unique REU program. The fourteen participating faculty members combined have trained nearly 684 REU students, leading to 80 peer-reviewed research articles co-authored by undergraduates. BU's strong commitment to undergraduate education and research will ensure the success of the proposed REU program. The broad and cohesive research interests of faculty mentors involved in this program allow for designing and implementing a vigorous summer REU program to offer T-shaped professional training opportunities to undergraduates. Efforts will be made to recruit students from underrepresented groups, such as women, minority students and students from undergraduate institutions and community colleges where undergraduate research training is limited. The outcome of the REU program will be disseminated at national conferences and published in peer-reviewed journals.

The REU program will provide students with opportunities to learn how engineering principles can be integrated with medical and life sciences to translate biomedical discoveries into bedside technologies for treating many diseases, such as diabetes and cancers. The program will expose students to medical science, biology, biochemistry, pharmaceutical sciences, neuroscience and cognitive science, as well as to tissue engineering, materials sciences, nanofabrications, genome editing, RNA transcriptome analysis, 3D bioprinting, cell manufacturing, and tissue biofabrication. Interactive workshops covering topics related to biomedical engineering and graduate studies and career development training will inform students of the latest developments in the fields of biomedical science and engineering and professional development opportunities in these fields. Social events related to the REU program will allow students to interact with other REU students on campus facilitating peer learning and collegiality. Field trips to industry sites will introduce students to applications of biotechnology development. The combination of research training, workshops, social events, and field trips will provide students with a foundation in biomedical engineering research, which they can apply to enriching their professional development.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

We developed a novel summer REU program that provided students intensive multidisciplinary and convergent training in integrated biomedical science and technology, and also equipped them with professional development tools related to collaboration and ethical practice. The program was launched in summer 2018. We trained 30 students in total. We skipped the summer 2020 due to the COVID pandemic. Table 1 summarized major outcomes of the phase I program.

Close to 90% of our REU trainees were students from underrepresented groups. Most of them were never exposed to research before this REU training. Rich lab research experiences advanced their knowledge and skills in biomedical science and engineering. The students expanded their knowledge in biomedical science and engineering and developed skills in organizing research ideas and research presentation after the training. By participating in the weekly research presentations and discussions, students learned from their peers and expanded their research interests and knowledge. These interactions stimulated their collaborations by which they learned from each other. The outcome of these trainings is remarkable. Almost every REU student trained was selected to present their REU research at the Biomedical Engineering Society (BMES) annual meeting (Table 1). Five of these trainees co-authored five peer-reviewed research articles in high impact journals. 

In parallel, we offered professional development training to inspire the REU students to pursue advanced degrees in biomedical engineering. We helped them to prepare their applications for graduate schools and for their GRE tests. The combination of research and professional development training delivered remarkable results. Nine out of the 10 REU students whom we trained in 2018 and five out of the 10 whom we trained in 2019 attended graduate or medical schools, including Binghamton University (our own graduate program). No data is yet available for our summer 2021 class, as the program has just ended. 

We have already established a national REU recruiting network that helped us to recruit very diverse REU students from different backgrounds as shown in Table 2. Our recruitment plan was based on actively recruiting members of underrepresented groups (women, minorities, and those with disabilities) to promote a diverse biomedical engineering workforce. Approximately 84% of trainees were selected from underrepresented groups and 50% of trainees were underrepresented minority (URM) students in our REU program. Students were selected from universities ranging from large research universities to small minority and/or undergraduate serving institutions. There were 65 in 2018, 218 in 2019, and 216 in 2021 applications to our REU program, reflecting 15%, 4.5%, and 4.6% acceptance rate in 2018, 2019, and 2021, respectively (Table 1). Most of the REU students listed our program as their first choice.

The program broadened the students’ knowledge and research experience in stem cell and regenerative medicine, 3D biomanufacturing, nanomedicine, bio-MEMS, biomaterials, nanobiotechnologies, genomics, neuroscience and engineering, and cognitive science and behavior engineering. The program offered ample opportunities for in-depth training that helped the students to gain a deep understanding of biomedical science and engineering and helped them to develop research skills needed for their success in either graduate school or a professional career. The graduate studies and career development training included in the weekly workshops further informed the students about graduate and career opportunities and paths for them to succeed in the early stages of their careers. The collaborative research setting and numerous social activities fostered a community among the REU students that helped them to develop a social network of biomedical researchers that meet the demands of biomedical research and industry.
